elements.text: [Part One]
Distant screams of agony and despair. Someone panting, and a squeaking sound.
Got to keep the wheel
Poor devil. No better than a hamster.
Why are you here? No, that’s not right. No, why am I is right. Why am I
Shut up, 47.
Why, why, why, why, why. [unintelligible]
Turning pages.
Good grief. Is that all people care about in the new century? Footballer’s haircuts and people who lost silly game shows? I don’t think I’ve ever been so glad I left.
The Tardis materialises.
At last! I was beginning to think you’d forgotten about me, Doctor. Doctor? Doctor, this isn’t particularly funny.
Tardis door opens.
Doctor? Where are you?
The moon is no longer the only satellite of Earth, as the Soviet Union has announced the successful launch of an artificial satellite, Sputnik.
Do you mind if I sit here?
(German accent) Not at all, Mister?
Louis. Just Louis. No luck at the Labour Exchange today?
No more than usual. I think the war is still to recent in people’s minds.
Hmm. It’s a pity, but it’s like this all over.
Ja. Yes. Oh, forgive my manners. What are you having?
I’m all right for now, but thank you. It’s so rare that people are so polite.
My parents said that at the turn of the century. I suppose my children will say the same at the turn of the next.
And complain about, nobody used to have to lock their doors.
Exactly. Ridiculous, isn’t it? There have been locks on the doors since at least Roman times, but people always say this.
It strikes me, Johannes - may I call you Johannes? - that a man like you deserves something better. What are you likely to get? Farm labourer?
How do you know that? How do you know my name?

Call it a talent I have. I know your name is Johannes Rausch, that you have a degree in metallurgy from the University of Vienna. I know you were a prisoner of war at Eden Camp in Yorkshire, and you stayed behind after the war to marry an English girl. Feel free to stop me if you’ve heard any of this before.
You’re from the Government, no? Checking up that I’ve got the right Party memberships? Or at least not got the wrong ones.
No, I’m not from the Government. I’m from a scientific institute. You won’t have heard of us. I just want to have a little chat about what we could offer you.
In metallurgy?
Unfortunately not. But before I put all my cards on the table, I want to get us over the question you'll have of whether I’m for real. What date is it today? The 15'"?
Yes. Why?
This afternoon, your daughter will call from university to say she’s engaged to be married.
You must be mad.
Well, maybe. But let’s say we meet again here at, say, 7, and discuss things a little further? For now I suggest you drink up and get home. You don’t want to miss the call.
Awake, are we? Control, K14 is awake. Care and maintenance need to be down here stat.
[OC]: Ah, good. I'll see to it immediately.
Something growling.
Indeed.

In international news, the Soviet Union has announced the successful launch of the world’s first artificial satellite, which joined our natural satellite, the moon, in orbit yesterday. Until this announcement, the series of radio signals being transmitted by the so-called
There you are. I was beginning to think you weren’t coming, which would have been most disappointing.
How did you know that Carol was getting married?
It’s my business to know things. I told you this because I didn’t want us to get into a long and boring argument about whether I was on the level for the kind of things I was and will be saying.
Such as?

Such as how I can help you improve your lot in life. Your heart’s desire is mine to give. Within reason, anyway. Obviously, if you want to rule the world with an iron fist, that’s not so good for me. But the usual things — a better job, winning the Football Pools, owning your own business — those I can do something with.
(laughs) You don’t look much like the Devil to me.

The horns and the forked tail went out of fashion ages ago. Look, it’s like this. I’m what you might call a speculator. I deal in the Futures market. Admittedly, I know some people who'd say that’s the same thing as being the Devil, but I’ll be honest with you. Our research gave us your name as someone who might be suitable for an arrangement we’re looking to make. Essentially, we use our contacts to help improve you life in return for your agreeing to certain terms.
And what's the catch in these terms of yours?
None At least, not within your lifetime.
My lifetime?
You're right, of course. For everything there is a price, and the price for this is that you agree to come with me wherever I may suggest, the day before your death.
The day before? I don’t imagine I'll be much good to you then, unless... you want to use my body for medical science?
Your body won’t be harmed, I promise. We want to study your brainwaves. Everything is recorded non-invasively. Electrodes, you know.
You must be thinking very far ahead. Why not get somebody who’s already old?
Environmental factors. We’re also studying what changes there will be to the brain as the world changes.
I always wanted to be a sculptor.
All you have to do is put your thumb print on this.
More violence in Irag, where US and UK forces say they are hours from final pacification. Despite this claim, there was more fighting today in the northern part of the city. In other news, over 140
Hello? Yes, I wonder if I could have a taxi sent out to the Fox Inn. That’s right, the one by the roundabout. Well, any time really. Thanks. I'll wait.
Door opens and closes.
Welcome back.
Thanks.
It went well?
He agreed, if that’s what you mean.
You collected all the relevant data?
This one isn’t going to be a security issue, Rigan. He’s an old man, or will be by the time you see him.
Maybe he'll be the one needing protection, then. It’s still a security matter. Damn it.
What is that?
I don’t know. I’ve had my guards search the Institute from top to bottom and not found anything.
Sounds like it’s in the walls.
You know how impossible that is.
Whatever you say.
I’m going to investigate. Klyst is waiting for you.
Louis. Back so soon?
It was an easy call this time, Professor.
Yes, I thought it might be.
He’s going to be a natural, isn’t he.
Not quite, according to the stochastic output, but close enough.
That’s not so bad. Have you got his pick-up point mapped out?
Everything you need is in this file.
Right. When will you need him brought to the Institute?
There’s no hurry that I can see. Tomorrow should be fine.
Vacuum cleaner. Doorbell.
Just a minute.
Vacuum off, door unlocked and unbolted.
Sorry about that. I was just... mein gott.

I’m sorry to startle you like this, Johannes. I would have preferred to make an appointment, but my schedule didn’t really allow for it, and I really wouldn’t get good rates on calls from the office. Aren’t you going to ask me in?
There you go, love. That'll be £5.20.
£5! I suppose it is the future.
Come again?
I’m sorry. I’ve been abroad for a few years. Keep the change.
Oh, ta, love. Is you going in?
Well, actually, I’m really following behind a couple of my friends. We’re going to a party and I was kind of hoping you could wait a few minutes...
I don’t mean to be rude, love, and I will shut up if you want, but you’re not a good liar, are you.
Does it show?
Yeah, like a big bright beacon. Checking up on your boyfriend, aintcha. I saw the bloke going into that house there. A girl’d be proud to shack up with him, I suppose. Not that I’m any judge.
You don’t look a day older. How is that?
Don’t worry. I am a day older.
But not fifty years. I’d almost forgotten. Ever since my first display and sale, I’d forgotten. It’s time, is it?
I’m afraid so. I have a car outside, and I’d like you to come with me, just like you agreed. I know you’re an honourable man, a man of your word. If there’s anything you need to collect?
Can’t I wait and tell my wife and daughter? See my grandchildren and say goodbye to them?

I’d like to say yes, I really would, but I’ve done this a lot of time, and believe me, this is the best way. Better for me, for you, and for them. I'll arrange for full documentation to be delivered, explaining the situation. They’ll get on with their lives.
If I refuse? Refuse to go.
Well, that’s your choice to make, but we did have a fair agreement, and unlike some people, you’ve had fifty years to prepare.
Can I leave a note for them?
Of course. Anything that makes you feel more comfortable.
Oh, there’s your boyfriend, love. Looks like he’s got his dad with him.
Please, stop calling me love.
Sorry, love. Miss.
It’s Mel, actually. I Know it’s a horrible cliché, but can you follow that car, please?
I certainly can.
Now, what am I going to do with you, 47?
Do tell. I love to be told things. Facts, ideas.
Do you like to hear stories, 47?
Stories, recordings, [unintelligible], all those kind of things are what memory is for.
Memory? Do you have any memories, 47.
Oh yes. Not as much as is gone, but there’s always some thing. Places, times, planets, environments.
And do you remember what you did in these places?
We did mainly, came, and went, gathered knowledge, explored. Exploring is good.
Hmm. That looks normal.
Normal?
For you.
You.
Unfortunately.
Normal is as normal does, or doesn't, if that’s what’s normal. Tell me the story you mentioned, or data.
Well, the story still isn’t finished, or if it is, I’m not sure how it started, so I can’t tell you it all. But I can tell you who you were, Doctor.
Doctor? Ah, I knew a doctor once. Several doctors. Many doctors. Wonderful beings, most of
them. Ah! Gone now, of course. Gone for a long time.
Look, that’s not my boyfriend. Actually, I don’t even know either of their names. I’m just trying to meet up with a friend who told me he’d be wherever they’re going.
All sounds a bit cloak and dagger, don’t it? You're not a police woman, are you?
No. Actually, I’m a computer programmer.
Oh.
Would it matter if I were? You don’t sound like you fancy the idea of having a police officer in your cab.
Well, I weren’t always a cabbie, were I.
Oh, what were you before?
Well, I was a sort of self-employed freelance bailiff and courier. Sometimes interpersonal security work at public gatherings.
You mean a bouncer who did debt-collecting on the side.
Yeah. Course I don’t do none of that now.
You found a better life, or a sense of responsibility?
Yeah, well, I didn’t have much of a choice. Bouncers now got to be certified that they ain’t got a criminal record.
Ah.
We're receiving Louis’ signal. He’s bringing the new subject in now.
Is anyone following him?
No.
Good. Drop the barrier and let him in. Have the new subject put in T46, please.
Yes, Professor.
A nursing home?
Not exactly. It’s the Klyst Institute.
Never heard of it.
You must be Mister Rausch.
Ja.
If you'll accompany these gentlemen, they'll show you to your quarters and get you settled in. Professor Klyst will see you shortly.
Oh, I see. Very well then. (leaves)
Think he’s worth the trouble?
Klyst does.
If you say so.
You seem troubled.
Being stuck here at the back end of the galaxy isn’t what I signed up for. Oh for... just listen to me . I’m even beginning to sound like them.
It may be the back end of the galaxy to you, but it’s still a vitally important end. And anyway, we’re not really that dissimilar, you know.
You and I?
Us and them.
I don’t know how you can stand it.
Stand what?
Connecting with them.
Just something I do.
It’s a talent I don’t envy you.
I'll try not to take that personally.
Thank you, gentlemen.
Door clangs shut.
Surprisingly civilised.
Turns a music player on and off, checks the water supply.
[OC]: Doctor’s to the right of me. Inside, outside, and not a drop to drink.
Door opens and closes.
Hello?
Hello. Goodbye. Hello. Same thing, really.
This door isn’t even locked. You could just walk out of here on your own two legs.
Just walk. Ah, yes. Legs. One in front of the other. Consecutively, not concurrently.
I should think you’d have to be pretty light on your feet to put both your legs in front of each other concurrently. What is that?
What is what? What is? Ah. What is.
That noise. It sounds like it’s coming from the skirting.
What’s outside is outside. What’s inside is even more of a mystery. More than I can tell, and I’ve tried, believe me.
You know, I’m grateful for the chance to chat, but I wish you didn’t sound so much like a fortune cookie.
Cookie.
Then again, this is some kind of mental home.
Mental?
Oh, I’m sorry. I didn’t mean to comment unfavourably.
Home? I’m home away from home. A home is I. I mean, home is me. Wherever you lay your hat. This is my hat. There, I’ve laid it.
Yes, I know the feeling. To go away somewhere for a rest. It’s under the floor. Maybe you should move to a different room.
I can’t go. I can’t stay. I’m just I, stuck here in this
The doors are unlocked, you know.
Windows, hatches, scopes, no difference. No difference when you're trapped and shackled.
Shackled?
Shackled.
I don’t see any shackles on you.
Shackled to him, trapped in me. Don’t you see? No, you're too limited. Not that there’s anything wrong with that. Limitations are fine if they're accepted and taken into account.
He won’t respond with any sense, Mister Rausch. I’ve tried every day since he er, arrived. His is the most tragic case we have here.
What happened to him? Was he born this way, or was he hit on the head or something?
There was a tragedy. If it’s at all possible, he’ll be restored, if...
You don’t sound confident.
How I feel has no bearing on the matter, Mister Rausch. Either it’s possible or it isn’t, whether I’m confident or just thinking wishfully.
Get out of car.
They drove through those gates. Do you know where we are?
Yeah, just outside Hetchell House. It’s a looney bin.
You mean it’s a mental care home.
That’s what I said.
I need to have a look around.
You be careful. Who knows what kind of people are in there.
Fancy giving me a protective hand, then?
No way. I’ve got to get back, and there is absolutely nothing you can say to keep me near this dump a second longer than I
Nothing? Maybe Edward Elgar can put in a good word for me.
Twenty, forty, sixty. Three hundred? Ten minutes.
This is going to sound very silly, Professor Klyst, but what year is it?
The same as when you left your house today. Why?
This place, it’s so
It’s very old, but I assure you we have the most modern equipment.
I don’t doubt it. But what exactly do you want with me?
Oh, just to conduct a few tests. It’s a survey of sorts.
Professor!
Yes?
It’s K14. He’s gone.
Gone? The Feladrin?
He could be everywhere.
Call a lock-down. I'll set up a scan from central control. You make sure Mister Rausch here is safe.
This is Commander Rigan. Institute full lock-down procedure on K wing.
Alarms, crashing barricades.
Hold positions until I arrive. What were you doing in 47’s room, Mister Rausch?
I heard him talking.
Did you now? Poor 47 is not well. Not well at all. He can’t move from here, you see, and it eats at him.
Paralysis?
I’m sure he’d like me to think so.
I didn’t expect, I mean, I’m not ill or anything. Why am I here now?
There will be a burglary tomorrow at your house. You and the criminal surprise each other, there’s a struggle, you’re stabbed.
Stabbed? How can you know this?
At least, you would have been, if you were still at home.
But if you knew about this, if you’d been tipped off, why not just stop the burglar, alert the police or something?
That’s not my business.
Not your...? What about the other people he'll burgle? Perhaps he'll kill one of them.
Perhaps he will. Don’t you have faith in your law enforcement agencies?
You’ve never been in a council estate in your life, have you, girl?
You’d be surprised where I’ve been.
So, this Hetchell House is pretty big.
Yeah. Give me the willies every time I come up here.
Mental illness isn’t contagious, you know.
You’ve never been to a football ground, have you. Try the bell. Well, looks like nobody’s home.
Surely there must be somebody. Night nurses, janitors. That’s weird.
What’s weird?
There’s no gap between this wall and this door. Not even a hair line. It’s as if the whole thing is one smooth surface and... This isn’t a door at all. It’s just moulded in.
K14 is still missing. Whose idea was it to have a Feladrin in the programme?
Yours. Not the worst decision you’ve made, but not the best. Letting the Doctor stay would probably be the worst. Speaking of whom, well Professor, there’s good news and there’s bad news.
Good?
I got an ID and bio on your patient 47, this Doctor of yours.
Bad?

Terrorist. The list of convictions and outstanding warrants would be the envy of anyone in the underworld. He has a penchant for overthrowing legitimate national governments and there are grounds for genocide charges. The docket includes numerous minor crimes as well. Theft, assault, sedition, kidnapping. You get the idea? He’s also, by the way, a Time Lord.
I know. What are you recommending? Execution?
No. Just that as a known criminal and terrorist, the Doctor be detained until he can be handed over to the proper authorities.
You know, I’ve known a lot of authorities in my time, and I’ve never known one I would describe as proper.
But you can’t just let him wander in his current condition. He’s certainly a danger to himself, if not others.
I don’t think he'll be a danger to others. If he was going to be, we’d have seen evidence of it by now.
Would we?
The others manifested their violent tendencies within a few hours. He’s... it’s been three days and no sign of turning violent.
Nevertheless, I’ve already had guards posted.
Rigan, if it is possible to cure him, I have to try.
Possible? It’s more than possible, Klyst, it’s a matter of decision.
I decided to cure him from the first moment the condition manifested itself.
I meant, it’s his decision.
His? He’s hardly in any decision to make one.
You don’t still believe that, do you?
Are you suggesting he’s faking it?
No, I’m saying I know he’s faking it.

Well, I wouldn’t go making bets about that with Louis if I were you. He’s not faking this. You cannot imagine literally what the condition must be like, for both of them. Oh, and Rigan? There’s something that you won't have found in this Doctor’s file. His scans show elevated levels of lindos in his cellular structure. He’s recently regenerated.
Love, up here.
I haven't climbed a tree since I was a girl.
There you go. Up you get.
What am I looking for?
You’ll know it when you see it. It’s the weirdest thing I’ve ever seen, and I’ve seen Blackpool in the morning.
What made you climb up here anyway?
I thought I might see a skylight, you know. Not that I’ve done this kind of thing before. Much.
(gasp) Where’s the roof.
That’s what I was wondering. Where is the roof, the floors, the interior walls?
This whole building’s just a hollow fake!

RIGAN: I’m going to investigate. Klyst is waiting for you.
KLYST: Louis. Back so soon?
LOUIS: It was an easy call this time, Professor.
KLYST: Yes, I thought it might be.

LOUIS: That’s not so bad. Have you got his pick-up point mapped out?
KLYST: Everything you need is in this file.
LOUIS: Right. When will you need him brought to the Institute?
KLYST: There’s no hurry that I can see. Tomorrow should be fine.
RAUSCH: Just a minute.
RAUSCH: Sorry about that. I was just... mein gott.
LOUIS: I’m sorry to startle you like this, Johannes. I would have preferred to make an appointment, but my schedule didn’t really allow for it, and I really wouldn’t get good rates on calls from the office. Aren’t you going to ask me in?
CABBIE: There you go, love. That'll be £5.20.
MEL: £5! I suppose it is the future.
CABBIE: Come again?
MEL: I’m sorry. I’ve been abroad for a few years. Keep the change.

RAUSCH: But not fifty years. I’d almost forgotten. Ever since my first display and sale, I’d forgotten. It’s time, is it?
